title: How Google is supporting the circular economy
summary: Google is committed to accelerating the transition to a circular economy in which business creates environmental, economic and community value through the maximum reuse of finite resources. Google has made it a core value to operate its business in an environmentally sustainable way and aims to achieve net-zero emissions across all of its operations and value chain by 2030, to replenish 120% of the water it consumes by the same year, and to become a circular Google within this more sustainable world.
green_innovation: TRUE, the article describes several examples of Google's green innovations, such as using recycled materials in its products, designing its data centers to be zero-waste, and developing new ways to recycle electronic waste.
business_innovation: TRUE, the article describes several examples of Google's business innovations, such as its new data center design, its food waste reduction programme, and its new Pixel phone made with recycled aluminum.
green_product: TRUE, the article describes several examples of Google's green products, such as its Pixel phone made with recycled aluminum, its Nest thermostat that helps users save energy, and its new data center design that is zero-waste.
green_process: TRUE, the article describes several examples of Google's green processes, such as its new data center design that is zero-waste, its food waste reduction programme, and its new recycling programme for electronic waste.
product_or_process: various products and processes, such as data centers, phones, thermostats, and recycling programmes
greenwashing: FALSE, the article does not describe any examples of greenwashing.

title: Aquafil – Helping Define the Circular Business Model of the Future
summary: The article discusses the need for businesses to transition to circular business models to drive a circular economy and reduce resource consumption. It highlights opportunities for circular business models in the interior design and architecture space, including products as services, product use extension, and take-back programs.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article discusses the need for businesses to transition to circular business models to drive a circular economy and reduce resource consumption. This is a green innovation because it reduces negative environmental externalities of human activity.
business_innovation: TRUE. The article describes circular business models such as products as services, product use extension, and take-back programs. These are examples of business innovations because they are new or improved business processes that differ significantly from previous business processes.
green_product: TRUE. The article mentions that Aquafil’s carpet recycling centers have provided Aquafil a way to take back nylon-based products like carpet and fabric scraps that would otherwise end up in landfills to create ECONYL® regenerated nylon. This is a green product because it is designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: FALSE. The article does not mention any green processes.

greenwashing: FALSE. The article describes an actual product and process innovation that provides environmental benefits.

title: Design issues concerning circular economy assessment methods at the product level: a comparative analysis through a case study of a mobile tiny house
summary: The article describes a tiny house prototype that was designed and built with sustainable materials, with the purpose of serving as a real-world laboratory in five locations of the Venosta Valley, Italy. The house was built with hemp bricks, spruce wood, larch wood, natural mortar, hemp fiber, and natural hydraulic lime. The tiny house prototype has a 25 square meters area and a weight of 12 tons. The house was assessed for circularity using six different methods, and the results showed that the house has a circularity score of between 40% and 65%.
green_innovation: TRUE, as the tiny house was designed and built with sustainable materials with a view to reducing negative environmental externalities.
business_innovation: TRUE, as the tiny house is a new product that differs significantly from the firm's previous products and that has been introduced on the market.
green_product: TRUE, as the tiny house is a good that is designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not describe a process innovation.

title: Best Bluetooth Speaker for 2024
summary: This CNET article discusses 12 of the best Bluetooth speakers in 2023, including the Tribit XSound Go, JBL Pulse 5, Anker Motion Boom, UE Hyperboom, Marshall Willen, Tribit StormBox, Bang & Olufsen Beosound A1 (2nd Gen), Sonos Roam, Bose SoundLink Micro, Anker Soundcore Motion Plus, Bang & Olufsen Beosound Explore, Monoprice Soundstage 3, and Tribit XSound Mega.

title: Target talks turning old car seats into adorable storage crates — and the future of its Target Zero initiative
summary: Target has a number of sustainability initiatives, including a car seat trade-in program, a focus on circular products, and a goal to eliminate single-use packaging. The company is also training team members and vendors in circular design principles.
green_innovation: TRUE, The article describes a number of green innovations, including a car seat recycling program, circular products, and reduced packaging.
business_innovation: TRUE, The article describes a number of business innovations, including a car seat recycling program, circular products, and reduced packaging.
